isis.stitle: SINGLE REDUCTION, TANDEM AXLES: SPICER J400-S, W460-S - INSTALL - RING GEAR AND PINION TOOTH CONTACT PATTERN

svcproc.title: RING GEAR AND PINION TOOTH CONTACT PATTERN

svcsubproc.title: Gear Tooth Nomenclature
svcsubproc.para: The toe of the gear tooth is the portion of the tooth surface at the end towards the center.
The heel of the gear tooth is the portion of the tooth surface at the outer end.
The top land of a gear tooth is the surface of the top of the tooth.

step1.para: To obtain correct contact pattern, paint ring gear teeth with marking compound and apply load while rotating pinion ( Figure 132).

figure.caption: Figure 131. Paint Ring Gear Teeth With Marking Compound

step1.para: The tooth contact patterns should have the same general shape and position as the ring gear teeth shown in Figure 133.

If the pattern is concentrated more toward the heel ( Figure 134), backlash must be reduced. Recheck backlash as described in DIFFERENTIAL, Step 6. To reduce backlash, loosen the right side adjusting ring until the measured backlash is within specification. The tooth contact pattern should now have the same general shape and location as shown in Figure 133. If the contact pattern still does not conform, less backlash than normal is required.

figure.caption: Figure 133. Ring Gear Out Too Far

step1.para: To avoid reducing differential bearing preload excessively, further loosening of the right side adjusting ring should be accompanied by equal tightening of the left side adjusting ring. Decreasing backlash moves the ring gear toward the pinion.

If the pattern is concentrated at the toe ( Figure 135), more backlash is required. Recheck backlash. To increase backlash, tighten the right side adjusting ring further until the measured backlash is within specification. The tooth contact pattern should now spread more across the ring gear tooth as in Figure 133. If the contact pattern still does not conform, more backlash than normal is required. To avoid increasing differential bearing preload excessively, further tightening of the right hand adjusting ring should be accompanied by equal loosening of the left hand adjusting ring. Increasing backlash moves ring gear away from the pinion.

figure.caption: Figure 134. Ring Gear In Too Far

step1.para: If a pattern is concentrated at the ring gear tooth root ( Figure 136), the pinion is too close to the ring gear. It must be moved out and away to establish its proper mounting distance and contact pattern as shown in Figure 133. This is accomplished by choosing a thicker pinion position cage shim. Re-adjust pinion-to-ring gear backlash, as required, once proper pinion mounting distance has been established.

If pattern is concentrated at the tooth top land ( Figure 137), the pinion is too far away from the ring gear and must be moved closer to the ring gear to establish its proper mounting distance and tooth contact pattern. This is accomplished by selecting a thinner pinion position cage shim. Re-adjust pinion-to-ring gear backlash as required once proper pinion mounting distance has been established.

After proper ring gear pattern is achieved, again tighten the differential bearing cap bolts to 275 to 320 ft-lbs. (373 to 434 Nm). Install adjusting ring retainers and new cotter pins of proper size ( Figure 138).

figure.caption: Figure 137. Tighten Differential Bearing Cap Bolts
